newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Stroeve says German problems threaten Sphinx.
newsitem.headline: Stroeve says German problems threaten Sphinx.

text.p: Brokerage Effectenbank Stroeve said on Friday the problems which ceramics maker Koninklijke Sphinx Gustavsberg has in Germany now seem to threaten the company's existence.

"The strategic step which was made a few years ago to enter the then promising German market has now jeopardises the whole company," Stroeve said in a report written after a presentation by Sphinx to financial analysts.
As competition from low-cost countries has halved ceramics prices in recent years, Sphinx's German units now cannot cover about 40 million guilders of their fixed annual costs.
Sphinx announced yesterday it would reorganise its German activities and had set aside a 30 million guilder provision for this, causing a 1996/97 net group loss of about 15 million.
Stroeve said Sphinx would drastically cut its production capacity in Germany and would axe about 130 jobs at two Belgian plants which supply the German branch.

By selling assets and the company's tile division, cutting supplies and cancelling investments, Sphinx should be able to reduce its debts a little. Its interest charges for the year to March 31, 1997, are seen at about 18 million guilders on an expected operating profit of only 10 million, Stroeve said.
The brokerage said Sphinx would reduce the number of its product series and would put more emphasis on profit contribution rather than on sales volumes.
Although Sphinx said developments in the Netherlands and Scandinavia were going much better, the company was still in a very difficult financial position, Stroeve said.
"In that perspective, we wonder whether the company would not have done better to completely withdraw from the German ceramics market," it added.
Stroeve said it does not expect Sphinx to become profitable again in the next two years.
